Indicator 01. # of women representatives in community-led governance structures in target locations (All Areas) Indicator 02. % of persons targeted for livelihood assistance reporting increased income-levels in target locations 06 months after having received support (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 03. # of persons targeted for micro-enterprise support reporting sustaining their enterprises 6 months after having received support (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 04. # persons using/accessing constructed/ rehabilitated infrastructure (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 05. % Increase in # of households reporting ‘more than 5’ occasions for interacting with a member from another village/ethnicity in past 06 months as a result of UNDP's interventions (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 06. % of households reporting perceptions of increased unity between people from other villages/communities in the past 6 months as a result of UNDP's interventions (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 07. % of trained participants who successfully apply the knowledge and skills on social cohesion gained from training initiatives into their work. (disaggregated by gender) Indicator 08. % of people surveyed who report that their level of trust toward others have increased as a result of their participation in training initiatives (disaggregated by gender) Indicator 09 . % Households purchasing technologies reporting and improved perception of women and youth as a result of market transactions facilitated by the programme (diaggregated by men and women) Indicator 10. # of Early Recovery strategies developed and implemented (national, Rakhine and Kachin); Indicator 11. Early Recovery principles integrated in humanitarian sector/ cluster response plans;

comment.narrative: Indicator 01. 25:100 women representatives in community-led governance structures in target locations Indicator 02. 0% of persons targeted for livelihood assistance reporting increased income-levels in target locations 06 months after having received support Indicator 03. % of persons targeted for micro-enterprise support reporting sustaining their enterprises 6 months after having received support Indicator 04. 300,000 persons using/accessing constructed/ rehabilitated infrastructure Indicator 05. 31% of households reporting ‘more than 5’ occasions for interacting with a member from another village/ethnicity in past 06 months Indicator 06. 0% of households reporting perceptions of increased unity between people from other villages/communities in the past 6 months as a result of UNDP's interventions Indicator 07. 0% of trained participants who successfully apply the knowledge and skills on social cohesion gained from training initiatives into their work. Indicator 08. 0% of people surveyed who report that their level of trust toward others have increased as a result of their participation in training initiatives Indicator 09 . 0% Households purchasing technologies reporting and improved perception of women and youth as a result of market transactions facilitated by the programme (diaggregated by men and women) Indicator 10. No Early Recovery strategies developed and implemented (national, Rakhine and Kachin); Indicator 11. 0 Early Recovery principles integrated in humanitarian sector/ cluster response plans;

Indiactor 1. 40:100 women representatives in community-led governance structures in target locations (All Areas) Indicator 2. 70% of persons targeted for livelihood assistance reporting increased income-levels in target locations 06 months after having received support Indicator 3. 80% of persons targeted for micro-enterprise support reporting sustaining their enterprises 6 months after having received support Indicator 4. 300,000 persons using/accessing constructed/ rehabilitated infrastructure Indicator 5. 46.5 households (50% increase) reporting ‘more than 5’ occasions for interacting with a member from another village/ethnicity in past 06 months Indicator 6. 50% of households reporting perceptions of increased unity between people from other villages/communities in the past 6 months as a result of UNDP's interventions (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 7. NA Indicator 8. NA Indicator 9. NA Indicator 10. Recovery Network Strategy developed for target locations (Rakhine and Kachin). Indicator 11. Integration of ER principles in at least 2 humanitarian sector/ cluster response plans

Support reached up to 196,571 people in 113 villages in Mon, Kachin, Kayin, Rakhine and Shan states. Key interventions included support to rural and flood and conflict-affected communities in Rakhine; support to returnees and host-communities in Kachin, and the roll-out of a pilot initiative to improve market-based livelihood opportunities for rural communities by increasing their access to innovative technologies in Mon, Kayin and Shan. In 2015, Capital assistance reached 113 persons (48% women); 23,107 (52% women) persons benefitted from access to new infrastructure; and 40 young entrepreneurs (65% women) have established businesses selling fuel-efficient and renewable energy products in their communities. By end-2015, up to 89% of those receiving capital assistance for agriculture, livestock and fisheries reported an increase in income and 100% of those receiving capital assistance for enterprises reported sustaining their enterprise, both 6 months following the receipt of support. The Programme also reported 47 female CBO members for every 100, an increase from a baseline of 25 persons, and 82% households reporting an increase in opportunities for interaction between different communities, an increase from a baseline of 46.5 households. While ongoing in 2016, 589 persons from a cross-section of local government, CSOs and none-state actors (ethnic armed organizations) have developed their capacities to train local stakeholders in six states.

activity-description.narrative: Addressing climate risk resilience through community based and community driven adaptation in decentralized settings in Mandalay.

description.narrative: first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Addressing climate risk resilience through community based and community driven adaptation in decentralized settings in Sagaing .

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: 1. Project launched through engagement of key government counterparts and involvement of stakeholders 2. Project target villages selected through a participatory process involving all the stakeholders 3. Project inception workshop conducted and inception report submitted 4. Project Steering Committee meeting conducted and Annual Work Plan for 2015 endorsed by the PSC 5. Preparatory activities for project implementation completed
All targets achieved, except for target 5, where work is still ongoing.

• 1 Water diversion canal constructed • 300 HH trained on SWC activities • 23.4 ha of tree planting activities on public land • 209 Ha of homestead gardening/agro-forestry plots established and 200 Ha of farm boundary plantations • 570 HH (510 farmer plus 60 Staff) are trained on climate-resilient farming methods (Primary target) • 20 Rice thresher and 120 multi-crop thresher provided • 140 thresher groups’ establishment • 1400 Persons received training event on transferring technical know-how climate resilient livestock practices from Livestock Department Officer to community members • 500 HH has increased diversity of livestock assets • 2 ToT training organized on CBDRM • One Agro-meteorological bulletin produced

•1 Shwebo Township Irrigation System renovation was completed to improve access irrigation and drinking water supply in Shwebo townships. 488 households (385 in project village and 103 in non-project village) will increase access to water for the agriculture purpose who are stayed in water scarce area and Shwebo city residents will access to safe water during flood and raining seasons. •Total 152 HH (140 farmers represented from 140 project villages and 12 government staff) are trained on soil and water conservation to store fresh water and reduce accelerated runoff and erosion, slowing down surface water so it will penetrate the soil better and increase sub-surface storage. After the project, trained persons will remain in the area as resource persons for land degradation control. •Activities on 23 ha of public land tree plantation and 200 ha of farm boundary plantation completed. •203 ha of Homestead gardening activities completed under establishment of agroforestry in the Dry Zone. •20 Rice Threshers and 107 Multi-crops threshers were delivered to the respective township DoA compounds. •27 Livestock Breeding and Veterinary Department staff had been trained on Climate-resilient livestock rearing and practices, then those trained staff had transferred community-level training to 5558 landless and farmers to improve fodder preparation and storage, rangeland management, disease control methods, fodder bank, livestock shelter practices and livestock banking system. •2 Training of Trainers (ToT) event on the Community Based Disaster Risk Management was conducted and 43 relevant government staff from 5 project townships participated the training. These officials will be able to provide an integrated capacity building package to the communities in at least 70 villages in next year when the formation of CBDRM in these villages will be rolled out. •Developed five customized monthly forecast for the project’s townships to enhance the quality of climate risk information.

- 20 water diversion canal constructed - 70 small scale water pumping systems installed - 56 communal water tanks installed - 40 shallow tube well and 10 deep tube well renovated or constructed - 75 communal ponds rehabilitated or constructed - 578 ha of land covered with soil and water conservation techniques - 150 person received training on soil & water conservation - 3,065 Ha of micro-watersheds are protected through natural forest conservation, community forest establishment and public land tree planting activities - 1,136 Ha of private and public land covered by community-based agroforestry plots and 650 Ha of farm boundary plantations - 7,725 HH receive training on climate-resilient farming methods - 9,240 HH participate in post-harvesting processing and storage in order to reduce climate-induced post-harvest losses - 3,000 HH has increased diversity of livestock assets - Conducted vulnerability assessment in 5 townships - Developed Climate Hazard mapping for 5 target townships - Produce 4 Agro-meteorological bulletins - 30 CBDRM committees are formed

•44 run off/flash water diversion canals were renovated - which is more than the annual target for 2017 (20 diversion canals). Runoff water from upper catchment or existing natural waterway is collected and diverted into village ponds where villages can access drinking water, water for domestic use and for irrigation. •75 water retention ponds were renovated - which have increased water availability during the dry periods – mainly for drinking and domestic use. •soil and water conservation trainings were imparted to 152 HH (140 farmers represented from 140 project villages and 12 government staff) in 2017 and altogether with 2016, all 280 villages representatives in the project townships received soil and water conservation training and soil and water conservation measures were applied on 852 ha of land in the 5 project townships. •While trying to obtain land approval, completed plantation in 2,624 ha of natural forest conservation area, 843 ha of community forest establishment, 325 ha of micro watershed management and 192 ha of public land. •In addition, community based agroforestry plot such as homestead gardening, modified taungya crops and demo plots have been established on 465 Ha of land and farm boundary plantations on 510 ha have been completed during the reporting period. •Promoted climate-resilient farming practices through a range of climate-resilient farming methods - alternate wet & dry technology (AWD), establishment of perennial trees (Thanakha and fruit trees), farmer managed seed multiplication, participatory demonstration plots, participatory varietal selection and farmer’s field school, which have benefited 1437 HH and 351 DOA staff in 5 project townships who shared these practices to 7365 HH in 2017. •9380 HH and 139 DoA staff participated in post-harvesting processing and storage activities in order to reduce climate-induce post-harvest losses and 722 farmers have been disseminated by the trained farmers. To introduce community-managed crop ha

Government of Myanmar and UN undertake as assessment that will support a transition from humanitarian aid towards development assistance in Rakhine State, and identify ways to promote social cohesion among different communities in Rakhine State.
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions

description.narrative: Human rights affairs
People in Myanmar live in a more peaceful and inclusive society, governed by more democratic and accountable institutions, and benefit from strengthened human rights and rule of law protection.

This initiation plan aims to operationalize UNDP Myanmar's support to the crisis in Rakhine stemming from security events in August 2017 and it's consequential impacts on civilian populations within the broader conflict context in Rakhine State.
